dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain. Christmas lights. A rusted out '56 Lincoln rattles  down the bleak boulevard. In it: JOE STEVENS, an angry, b man in his late 20's, beside him his 10-year-old son, JOE JR. Joe Jr. stares out the window at passing: boarded buildin whores with raincoats over their heads trying to flag dow john, a black Santa, a knot of drinkers. Breaking the sil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at a light. Joe Stevens tries to furtively snor little something. He spots Joe Jr. watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firm, without irony) Don't you do this shit, boy. Don't  you ever fuckin' touch it, you hear  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Jr. stares, silent; Joe Jr.'s about to hit him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You hear me, goddam it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy nods. Satisfied, Joe Sr. draws in the stuff. It m him feel good, strong, worried and determined all at once

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; charged  up) What do you want for Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (light changes; he  accelerates) You don't know?? You gotta know what  you want, boy, if you ever expect to  get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden charm to his bravado. Joe Jr. smiles uncertainly Joe Sr. grins back, pulls up in front of a liquor store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wait here. This won't take a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Jr. doesn't notice or doesn't remark that his father, just before entering the store, draws a handgun from bene his coat. The boy gazes dreamily at the street. The lunatic Black S marches by, ranting to himself ("Then the white man say.. The RAIN HAMMERS on the roof and windshield. Joe Jr. brea on the glass, fogging the scene. From the store: MUFFLED GUNFIRE. Joe Jr. looks that way. Another GUNSHOT, then: His father comes out the door clutching money in one hand He strides toward the car with a reckless pride. He doesn notice: The liquor store door opens behind him. A SHOTGUN BLAST. Joe Stevens' guts splatter onto the car  windshield. A look of terrible amazement; he sinks to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps from the car, kneels by his father. The STORE OWNER (47, Slavic) drags the gun toward them,  bleeding profusely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enraged, almost to  tears) Fuckin' niggers... fuckin' niggers...

dialogues.speaker: JOE STEVENS
dialogues.text: looks at the money in his hand: two 20's, two 5's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty bucks... fifty goddam bucks. (looks up at his son) I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stuffs the blood-soaked bills in the boy's shirt pocke and dies. Joe Jr. looks up at...

dialogues.speaker: THE STORE OWNER
dialogues.text: Bloody, nearly unconscious, he aims the shotgun at the bo who is too frightened to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man dies on his feet. As he falls backward, he pulls trigger, the BLAST shattering the car windows. Cop cars SQUEAL up. Uniformed cops leap out, guns drawn,  survey the scene. Then one notices Joe Jr., staring motio at his father and the store owner, dead together. ON HIS

dialogues.speaker: THOSE SAME EYES
dialogues.text: -- but older, harder, colder. They're concentrating on a  paper before him.

dialogues.speaker: THE MINNESOTA MULTIPHASIC PERSONALITY INVENTORY
dialogues.text: Hundreds of TRUE/FALSE questions... 1.) I have never indulged in any unusual sexual practices (T/F)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2.) I have often felt that strangers were looking at me  critically. (T/F) 3.) When I was young I occasionally stole things. (T/F) Joe Stevens marks these TRUE, FALSE, FALSE then comes to: 4.) A person's station in life is at least partially  determined by his race. (T/F) We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-seven Black Cleveland police officers (many in uni including Joe) are taking the MMPI. Some roll their eyes the questions. Some try to copy answers. Others, like Joe work with rapid concentration. But he gets stuck on #4. Marks it false. Erases it. Marks true. Erases that. Ponders. Goes on to: #5. At times I he so well it bothers me. (T/F) He marks that true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERALD CARVER, 36, an ambitious government lawyer with a  relaxed, vaguely hip manner, looks over the file of the  ingratiating BLACK OFFICER sitting across the desk from h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Leland? You know the  difference between a black man and  nigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leland is startled, insulted, but doesn't want to blow th interview. He smiles weakly, shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; pleasant  smile) Yeah, most niggers don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stung, Leland tries to laugh. Carver puts his file aside, picks up another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECOND BLACK OFFICER is powerfully built, politically  conscious, takes no shit. Carver's leafing through his fi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Winston, what's the difference  between a black man and a nigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston is out of his chair before the question is finish drags Carver by the shirt front halfway across the desk a hisses into his face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck do you think you're  talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver smiles cheerfully past Winston's cocked fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonplussed by this cool dismissal, Winston stalks out. Ca picks up the next file, unfazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Stevens watches Carver reading his file and waiting f an answer. When none is forthcoming, Carver glances up, f Stevens looking right back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nigger's the one who falls for  your bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it pleasantly, without belligerence. Carver smile he's found his man. He offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerald Carver, United States District  Attorney. Call me Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A TV SCREEN: a grainy black-and-white tape, date and t stamped at the bottom. A grungy street, palm trees. The l from the monitor dimly illuminates Carver and Stevens. On SCREEN the CAMERA finds: A MAN in jeans, sneakers and  sweatshirt on a street corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ought to be wearing a sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell he's a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens laughs: it's obvious. A real DRUG DEALER joins the cop. UNDERCOVER COP: "You go it?" DEALER: "In the motel, right over here..." The Cop's uneasy, keeps glancing back toward the CAMERA as they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps looking for his back-up.  Now, the other guy knows it, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why's he taking him to the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (why else?) To rip him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver studies Stevens in the darkness, impressed. ON SCREEN: The figures disappear into the motel. We hear  their voices. DEALER: "Here, try some of it." UNDERCOVER  COP: "Uhh... No, I don't..." DEALER: "Why not, you  sonofabitch?" Two bursts of SOUND DISTORTION. A plainclothes cop, TAFT, (black, stocky, powerful) bolts from behind the CAMERA, sprints toward the motel. The CAM wobbles after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON SCREEN: The CAMERA (jerky, hand-held) nears the open m door. Taft is bent over the Undercover Cop's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Bobby... Jesus, Jesus... (to the CAMERA) Get an ambulance -- and back up.  Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the wall, starts past the CAMERA. Carver pushes pause button; the tape freezes on a jerky image of Taft's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (focussed on Taft) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Taft. LAPD Narcotics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a great cop. Two [names citation]  and a [another citation]. As tough  as they come and twice as honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver watches Stevens watch Taft, smiles at something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the cops aren't getting it done  here, are they? Gotta try something  new...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a manila envelope, dumps the contents on the des driver's license, social security card, high school  transcript, prison records... all in the name of William Hull. No photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who's John Hull?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are. If you want to be. (off Stevens) Most undercover guys don't know what  they're doing because it's a day  gig. (indicates dead cop  on TV) I need somebody who goes under and  stays there; six months, a year,  five years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he have to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy drugs. Sell drugs. Feed me  information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a snitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a drug dealer. A criminal. A  scumbag. But for the right side. (beat) I want you to come to Los Angeles on  loan to the Justice Department as a  federal agent. Your experience there  will be credited toward your seniority  here. And you'll come back to  Cleveland a P3 or higher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) I can't do that. I've got a wife and  kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're separated from your wife,  she's filled for divorce. You see  your kids every other weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens takes a breath: this is awkward to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a confession) All my life I've stayed away from  that stuff. I've never touched drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tolerant) Come on, a little grass...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not grass. Not nothing. I never even  had a drink. (his motto) Never have, never will. You don't  understand. I made a choice in my  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to understand? You saw your  father killed when you were ten, and  you decided you wouldn't be like  that. (off Stevens' surprise,  Carver grins) I'm God, I know everything. You wanted  to be a good boy, so you became a  cop. Hiding out in uniform... That's  why you got the hard-on for Taft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening Joe's file;  as if reluctantly) I'll tell the truth, Joe. You're  never going to be a Taft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at MMPI results) You ever take a look at your  psychological profile? You score  almost like a criminal. (reading) "Resents authority..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Exaggerated moral standards, but  with no underlying value system."  Look at the anger, the repressed  violence, it's almost off the scale...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver hands him the scores which are, of course, just  clusters of numbers. Stevens is upset, though oddly  unsurprised, as if this only confirmed his secret fears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you join the force?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward, but felt) I wanted to be of use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now you can be. You won't be  Taft, but maybe you'll be something  more... interesting. (sits back) There's a man named Ramon Gallegos  who supplies 60% of the cocaine to  the West Coast. He's smart, smooth,  and sufficiently elusive that we  don't even have an adult photograph  of him. However, his uncle is Hector  Guzman, an important Latin American  political figure. Gallegos uses  Uncle's connections to get product  into the country, and everyone we've  sent after him has ended up like  that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indicates dead body on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I be different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already are, that's the point... (indicates file, test  scores) You've got the ability and the  personality to go underground and  blend in completely. That's what the  others couldn't. Some part of them  showed. That's why they're dead.  See, there's only one rule in this  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens raises his eyebrows: what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't blow your cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens parks outside a small, well-maintained house. As gets out, he spots a GROUP OF KIDS (black and Hispanic)  playing down the street. He's not pleased about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to them) Joe-J, Carmen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOY, 7, and a GIRL, 5, (both light-skinned) run to him  shouting, "Daddy," jump into his arms, competing for  attention, as if they haven't seen him in ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing with those kids? JOE-J & CARMEN Playing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (displeased) Your mom lets you play with them? JOE-J & CARMEN Yes, sir... Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His strictness has already sobered their enthusiasm. Sens this, he attempts to embrace them which he can do only  awkwardly. Meanwhile, his wife, TERRY (Southern white) has come out screen door. She and Stevens bristle at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we talked about this. The  older brother up there's got a sheet  with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay off it. They're just kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both are ready to fight, but restrain themselves. A big  Polynesian, TITO comes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tito...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of surprise, then he gets it. He looks to Terry. She gives a little shrug, refusing to be embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens is trying to seem interested in Carmen's little  drawings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're real nice, honey. Is that a  horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Daddy! It's a bunny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I don't want you to go away, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my work. I've got to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over her shoulder he sees Terry sitting with a subdued Jo J. Her face seems to say, "See, I told you..." Avoiding t accusation, Stevens notices a bruise on Carmen's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What happened to you there, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tito did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly outraged) He hit you?! (up in a fury) God damn it, what's he doing touching  her? I'm gonna...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry intercepts him on his way out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was running behind his chair  when he got up. It was an accident. (he's uncertain) A complete... total... accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens looks at Carmen who giggles. He's humiliated by h own temper, attempts to calm himself. Terry puts a sympat hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The immense sprawl, the arterial flow of the freeways, th blinding light. We DESCEND...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People getting off, among them the former Joe Stevens, no known as JOHN HULL. He's carrying a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull goes up the stairs onto a downtown street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South L.A. neighborhood. A 13-year-old BLACK YOUTH sellin drugs through a car window. Hull walks by. He's at ease,  looking around, his manner subtly announcing that he belo here, just as in the train station he seemed to belong am the commuters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fat BLONDE WOMAN (61, large white glasses, tiny shoes)  leads Hull down a corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Television mostly. I was on "Sky  King" twice, "Ramar of the Jungle."  That was a silly show. The jungle  was mostly flats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass an open door where a 6-year-old boy, JAMES, a  latchkey, sits on the stoop playing Gameboy; inside, his  mother, BELINDA, a broken down whore, is doing her nails drinking Pepsi. She looks up, bats her lashes at Hull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You want my advice, I'd stay away  from that bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door to the room across the hall. A dump. H walks in, drops his duffle: he'll take it. The Blonde lou in the doorway. He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull empties his pockets on the dresser. Looks at his mon room key, identification. Looks at himself in the mirror. touches his clothes, his face, tries on different express (NOTE: Throughout the film, Hull continually checks himse out in mirrors, both to adjust his appearance to the  circumstances and as if in an attempt to recall who he  "really" is.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the seam between South-Central and USC. Lots of people out: children, students, dealers, whores. Hull with a new haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dealers (most in mid-teens) meeting cars, making transact All this casually observed. EDDIE comes up the street,  reciting his version of an old street toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the day of the King's castration,  all the counts and no accounts were  down on the deck with Georgia Tech  taking turns in the back seat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those dealers not at car windows, gather around. He never speaks to them, goes on declaiming as he exchanges drugs money. Hull watches, talking to another street person. His appea continues to change: clothes, posture, walk, gestures sub conform to the environment, a bit like Zelig. Throughout film his appearance shifts, depending on who he's with. W always recognize him, but each time he's different. He walks up to a dealer, makes a quick buy and keeps goin But he sees them and is seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull drops eleven foil balls on a green blotter. Carver c out money for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits at the window, eating a burrito, watching little  James play in the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull approaches another Dealer, the 13-year-old seen earl (angelic face). Like Hull, he's trying to act tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice just changing) Nickel rock, dime rock. Excellent  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull exchanges a folded twenty for two foil balls. He wal off. He has gone twenty feet when...

dialogues.speaker: RED RANGE ROVER
dialogues.text: SQUEALS to a stop opposite the Dealer. A huge young black man, IVY (23, all in red with a red  headband), leans out the passenger window, shouting at th 13-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck I tell you about being  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone turns to look, but Hull's view is blocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too fuckin' late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POPPING noises. Ivy is waving an automatic weapon. Everyo on the street but Hull has hit the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying it, shouting) Get down, motherfuckers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivy laughs and fondles a girlfriend as the car ROARS off. sees Hull, pretends to fire, laughs as Hull, too, ducks.  When Ivy's gone, he runs to where a CROWD has gathered  around...

dialogues.speaker: THE 13-YEAR-OLD
dialogues.text: lying in the street, a bullet hole in his head, eyes open He twitches and kicks, blood pulsing from the neat wound. Then he's dead. The faces around him (young, old, many ra watch with a variety of emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?... Why'd they shoot him?...  Ivy did him, man... He's in the wrong  fuckin' place... That poor boy...  Get his beeper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops push through to the body. As the crowd disperses, Hu can't take his eyes off the boy. When he finally does, he sees Eddie, drink in hand. Their eyes meet, and Eddie, a  rapper, raises his eyebrows in brief acknowledgment of so

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) He done done, ain't he?

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: A bar with a neon bird for a sign. Hull enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A racial mix. Hull takes a seat at the bar. Stuffed birds line the lintel above the bottles. A female BARTENDER (lo red nails) greets him familiarly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without being asked, she sets him up a Dry Sack with a lo red straw. (NOTE: He never touches the drink.) Hull's  appearance has continued to change. His clothes have beco flashier, he has an earring, the start of a goatee. Eddie approaches the bar compulsively reciting one of his toasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) "Where's the Queen," said the King.  "She's in bed with laryngitis." "Is  that bastard still in town?... Fuck  the Queen," said the King, and ten  thousand knights straaaained at their  utmost... (to the bartender) Pina colada times two and a white  wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes on muttering under his breath, tapping his foot l any crankhead. He notices Hull, greets him as someone he  can't place but knows he's seen around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) How you doin', Dudley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tries to remember name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, man, right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clasp hands. Eddie takes his drinks, carries them to...

dialogues.speaker: A TABLE
dialogues.text: where he rejoins a white man, DAVID ELIAS (30s, slick,  powerful) and a well-dressed BLACK WOMAN (mid-20s, good- looking). She gets the wine. Elias rises to let her out. As the woman passes Hull on h way to the restrooms, their eyes meet: an instant of perf chemistry. He's struck. Her features open, grow sensual f a moment, but then, as if seeing something she doesn't li her eyes flick away, and she walks by as if he weren't th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: Hull invariably meets Carver in this anonymous roo distinguished only by the green blotter and a view of the city. This simple regularity suggest visits to a psychiat Carver probing, testing, teasing, trying to draw Hull out And they feel like therapy, at once a respite and a torme More foil balls on the blotter beside boxes of 3x5  photographs. Photos of Eddie and David Elias are up on a  corkboard, the beginning of a pyramid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie something... a motormouth...  he supplies the street dealers...  buys from him... (reads name on back  of photo) David Elias... who apparently buys  from a guy named Barbolla or  something. But I haven't seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver produces a photo of a handsome Latin in his 50s, p it on the board above Elias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa, Felix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was also a woman, but she's  not here. (as Carver reaches in  a drawer) I saw a kid killed. Twelve, thirteen  at the most. Turf war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver shrugs: these things happen. He hands Hull a lot o cash, much more than expected. Hull does understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get to Elias. Then to Barbosa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't rush this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rush it, please. I want art, John,  not reality. Budget hearings start  in April, and I need Gallegos by  then. They won't give us funding for  three ounce buys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not just doing this for the  funding, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without funding, we aren't doing it  at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virtual darkness save splinters of light between the curt Pipes burn here and there in the gloom. Ten or fifteen  crackheads huddle around a battery-operated TV on which T Brokaw is narrating an NBC documentary on drugs. A 12-yea old sits against a wall too stoned even for television. Hull approaches Eddie, regally installed on an automobile bench seat-cum-sofa, a lit pipe in one hand. We barely no the redhead kneeling between his legs, face buried in his crotch. He greets Hull from wrecked bliss. They know each other now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My man, Dudley, he's so fud-ley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull greets Eddie, some of the others, drops familiarly o an adjacent auto seat. The patrons are making fun of Brok laughing, exchanging fives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, man, I need...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie holds up a hand telling Hull to wait. His mind is  elsewhere. His features contract in brief concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever happened to that Drug Czar  motherfucker?... He gave up 'cause  he finally realized he didn't know  nothing about any of that shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter, etc. Eddie's concentration peaks, breaks o into a sigh and a smile. Eddie sings a satisfied little song... The redhead rises from Eddie's crotch, and we see it's a  boy, seventeen going on death; he might have been pretty year ago. Eddie passes him the crack pipe, lets him suck greedily f a few seconds before ripping it out of his scabrous mouth and offering it to Hull, who, with a grimace that gets la declines. The others continue to watch and comment on the speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is it you need so bad, blood?  Need, need, need??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whole K, quick as you can get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed, a trace  of envy) Comin' in the world, Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winning grin) All because of my man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie likes that, holds out a hand. Hull hits it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull nods, rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Stick around, let the bitch Hoover  you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indicating redhead. In all these scenes, Hull acts indifferent to the horror, but here the effort costs him. He masters his disgust wit joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you Clorox him first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs, even the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie comes out the back door of a building, is immediate collared by Taft (the cop on the videotape). He's in his 40s, stocky, balding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerful, gregarious) Eddie Shitface! Where you been, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie breaks free, runs three feet before HERNANDEZ (a  muscular Mexican) knees him in the groin. Eddie crumples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Eddie, I don't think I introduced  you to my new partner, Michael  Hernandez...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, Mr. Shitface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie folded over his wounded nuts. Hernandez and Taft si on crates to either side. The drugs they've taken from hi are neatly arranged on a garbage can lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the right to remain silent...  You have the right to an attorney...  You have the right to go back to  Ontario for eight-to-ten on a second  offense...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in several kinds of  pain) Oh, man, I can't go back in there, I  just can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothing) 'Course you can't, child, 'course  you can't. That's why you're gonna  start giving us some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasant, Santa Monica neighborhood. Spanish style hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasant, tasteful. Elias's wife, NANCY, (dressed like th attorney she is) sits in an alcove-study reading a real e contract through half-glasses. Elias himself is helping h daughter, MIRANDA, 7, with her homework. He is 38, with t body and bearing of a powerful man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again. Three times four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias is not a sweet Daddy. It should make us uncomfortab to watch him push his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You're adding again, you have to  multiply. Three and four is seven.  Three times four is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three times five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up; more  about the answer  than the door) Damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I just use a calculator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three men: FELIX BARBOSA (whose photo we saw in Carver's  office). Barbosa is a veteran of the coke business, but h doing too much of the drug now; he's sweating, paranoid,  unstable. With him is GOPHER, early 60s, a wizened high-v old con who Barbosa keeps the way Spanish kings kept dwar for amusement and luck; like the court jester, Gopher can say anything he wants without fear. Behind them is an His kid, CHINO, 17, a thug. Elias knows them all, but is not happy to see them at his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a problem, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend Eddie just started bending  over for the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very bad news. Elias murmurs a shaken, "Shit..." steps outside, half-closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) They busted him, and he's dealing to  save his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is how he'll lose the skinny  little thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he give us up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, but he will if he has to,  and eventually he'll have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy! I thought we were doing my  homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he'd talk about us.  He'd try not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we whack him, he definitely won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Miranda) Just a second. (to Barbosa) Not yet. Let me check on this, first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taunting) Nobody said you had to do the dirty  work, David. I'll take care of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix, if he's a problem, we'll kill  him. I'll kill him myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't realize until it's too late that Nancy has jus then opened the front door to see where he went. They loo at each other, a terrible moment: she knows what he does, hates it, can't bring herself to leave him, hates herself for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nancy, get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you; it's Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a cordless phone, goes inside closing the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a tasty wife, David. No wonder  you don't want us coming here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warning him) Don't talk about her that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't help it, David, it's his  nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone, chipper) Eddie... Sure, man, what do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias joins Eddie and Hull to one side. In the b.g. two g sparring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, this is John, John, David.  Eddie, this is Eddie. Everybody ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Elias) So what's this, you want to meet me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charming, touch of  mockery) I like to know the important  customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull makes a show of weary patience, gestures: here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're taking a lot of weight for a  guy we hardly know. Where're you  moving this stuff, John? We haven't  seen you around. We like to have a  sense who your customers are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, come on, man, do Macy's tell the  Gimbel motherfuckers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; watches him) Eddie, forget this guy, he's a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: ON HULL
dialogues.text: He's blown it. He's been made. The crushing failure. He  rallies himself to indignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this shit, Eddie? I thought  you were the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's sickened, wants to get paid, owes Taft a bust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's the fuckin' man. Go to your  place. I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taft and Hernandez, watching the gym. Hull comes out, loo up and down the street carefully. Taft sits up, pays  attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our collar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hernandez grunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some scumbag...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Taft clearly thinks there's something different about Hull. He's not sure what, but it troubles him. (NOTE: Hul makes a little move that Taft will later realize was a co move. For now he can't quite place it.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pleading his case to Elias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no cop, David. He's an animal.  You see his eyes? You never see a  cop with those eyes. I know this  shit, man, you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him an opening) What's going on, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six thousand cash is what. We  need it, David. We're behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias studies Eddie: is he a rat? Elias hopes not, but he going to find out. He hands a fat Federal Express envelop through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a warning) I want him to get it all, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie bows in gratitude, hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull's unlocking his door when Belinda, the hooker across the hall, comes out to talk. Her 6-year-old, James, watch silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a crackhead) Mr. Hull... Mr. Hull...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) What's happening, Belinda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you know, Mr. Hull, I was to the  welfare this afternoon, but the bus,  you know what I'm saying?... the one  bus, and then the other, and when I  got there they'd gone and changed  the time on me, without notification.  They's supposed to give notification,  ain't they? They said I got a thing  in the mail, but I don't remember, I  don't think they sent it, so now I'm  off the welfare, plus I forgot to  take James for his shot... for the  school? Which otherwise they let him  go. And he's gotta learn, he's gotta  learn, don't he, Mr. Hull, you tell  him, so's he can better hisself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull slouches in the doorway, fingers to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to James) You had any food today, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disclaiming any need) I had Ding-Dongs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs, gives him  money) You go to the Mexican place over  there, and get the chicken tostada  or the beef and bean burrito or both.  And a milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like milk. I want a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an order) You get the milk! And get something  for your mother, too. (to Belinda) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Hull, if you just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to James) Two tostadas, two burritos, two milks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gives him another bill. The boy runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You now, I look out for my James  best I can, Mr. Hull, but it's hard.  Now you like the boy, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull grunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I know you do. And I was thinkin' if  you wanted to take care of him, that  might be good for him. Give him a  male figure to look up to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Belinda, I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could just give me something  for him. Say five thousand dollars... (off Hull's shock) Or maybe four thousand. I couldn't  give up my boy for less than four  thousand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull is rescued from this horror by the ringing PAY PHONE He runs down the hall, grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. I'm here... Where?... five  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dashes past Belinda into his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you could just give me a part  now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door, takes the money Carver gave him out f behind the mirror, dashes back outside. As he rushes by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Let me do somethin' for you, Mr.  Hull. Let me do a little somethin'  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps going. The Blonde Woman addresses Belinda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No solicitin' in the halls. I told  you that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spunkier than we've  seen) I ain't doin' shit. Bitch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handful of customers under a mud sky. The THROB of a di helicopter. Hull pulls into the lot beside Eddie's BMW. He climbs into the BMW, tosses Eddie a brown envelope; mo spills onto his lap. Eddie does a quick count, produces t Fed Ex envelope. The usual white stuff. Hull's about to taste when the chopper swoops in with a s blinding overhead light. A BULLHORN booms down like the v of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the police. Remain inside  the vehicle. Place your open hands  against the windshield so that they  are clearly visible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a strategy) Spread the floor, Dudley. (rap sound effects  with rhythmic head  spasms) A-ga, a-ga, a-ga, a-ga...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie starts the car, and Hull rolls out the passenger do as the BMW races across the lot. Two black-and-whites and an unmarked converge on the stan Hull can't reach his car. He vaults a metal rail and runs off between two buildings. Hernandez jumps out of an unmarked and races after him. T speeds the car out onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: HULL
dialogues.text: running. Police and SIRENS pursuing. He hurls the Fed Ex  envelope into a dumpster. HELICOPTER light sweeps over hi As he cuts around a building, Taft opens a car door right into his face. Hull goes down hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into car radio) Thank you kindly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves at the helicopter which goes away, kneels over H who is twitching spastically on the ground, gasping for a Hernandez arrives carrying the Fed Ex envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) How you doin', child?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull is astonished to look up and see Taft looming over h the man he remembers from the videotape. He tries to spea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) You...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briefly puzzled) Me? Of course, it's me. You know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull shakes head, winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hurts, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull tries to curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Here, I want to show you something.  You have kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his wallet, opens it to pictures of his two  children, a boy and a girl, seven and eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) These are mine. Aren't they the most  beautiful children you ever saw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull groans, twists in pain. Taft sticks the pictures in face. Hull is affected by the children despite everything

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yeah, I know, they kind of leave you  speechless. So let me ask, if someone  put a gun to your baby's head,  wouldn't you kill him if you could?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull just looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Me, too. And you're the bastard with  the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the Fed Ex envelope from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarse; his first  words) You know the difference between a  nigger and a black man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't jive me, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nigger's the one covers Whitey's  ass by puttin' the brothers in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taft yanks him hard to his feet; Hull cries out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull is led in with other handcuffed PRISONERS. Carver is here, catches Hull's eye. Hull shakes his head; doesn't w Carver to intercede. A woman PUBLIC DEFENDER (26, attract harried) addresses the prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Shelley Weissbrod. This is  only an arraignment, a preliminary  hearing, but if you don't have money  for an attorney, the Public Defender's  office can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull is listening to this when a BAILIFF taps his shoulde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got counsel. Over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled, Hull sees the back of a suit conferring with a  PROSECUTOR. The suit turns. It's DAVID ELIAS who smiles,  offers his hand. Hull is stunned. Elias enjoys that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lawyer??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who hired you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) It's pro bono. If you don't want me,  there's Shelley. She's good. She  just can't provide special services...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling the next  case) John Hull...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting your case called first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias addressing the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Your Honor, I believe the preliminary  police toxicology report will show  that the substance seized from my  client was Mannitol, a baby laxative.  We move for immediate dismissal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull is surprised at this news. The Judge looks to the  Prosecutor who waives objection. Gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Hull) We're out of here, Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk toward the back, Taft approaches Hull. There already a deep pull between these two, and in Taft's pres Hull can't sustain the tough street act. We almost see th little boy inside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hull, amused) Baby laxative, they sold you some  bad shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hull) You have a constipated baby, and  you're in jail? What kind of a father  are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A father who don't know his own  children, ain't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long look between them, broken when Elias takes Hull's  arm, leads him away. Elias cheerfully greets a couple of  hookers waiting arraignment. Hull furtively grabs his sle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) You sold me Mannitol, motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his) If it hadn't been, asshole, you'd be  in jail right now... Come on, I want  you to meet some people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After hours. The place is closed. A couple of cars in the lot. Elias's BMW pulls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted except for one table where Eddie, Barbosa, Gophe and Chino are eating shrimp. They look up as Hull and Eli approach. Eddie's astonished to see Hull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley, Dudley, Fo-Fudley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprised to see him, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie looks around, uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) John got busted and kept his mouth  shut. Can't say that for everybody,  can we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying? Are you saying  me? Are you saying something about  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the truth, Eddie. Be honorable.  It's all you got left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, you little faggot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops made you give them somebody.  We know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie looks around. Everybody's looking at him. He consid lying, but realizes it's pointless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, so what? I mean, so what,  man? You got the money. Twenty-six  G. Twenty-six, David. Count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you might trade us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. (turns to Barbosa) Never, Felix, never. Come on, man,  you know I'd never...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull observes Barbosa become the power center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I know you never will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix, no. Don't be... I'm worth  money to you. Let me give you money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? You don't owe me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another twenty-six grand... Just to  show you... Fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not a hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (that's so much) A hundred??? Felix...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa's impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay, a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Twenty-four hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. Ten seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix, I need time. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One... two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have it right now. But I can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) Then goodbye, Eddie. I forgive you  for what you said to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) Twelve hours. Tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six... seven... (to Elias) You want to do it, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias looks stricken. Barbosa laughs. Eddie jumps up. Hul turns away, can't bear to watch this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nine...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: grabs the first thing he lays eyes on, a tiny snail fork plunges it into Barbosa's neck. As if it were a fly bite, Barbosa flings the table aside  and, with a long knife already in his hand, guts Eddie fr groin to breast bone. Eddie falls like a suddenly emptied sack. Elias can't help gasping. Hull looks away, hiding his horror. Barbosa rips the fork out of his neck and hurls it at the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piece of shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias stares at Eddie's body, transfixed. Horrified,  fascinated, afraid, in awe. Barbosa turns to Hull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What'd you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least it was clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased, to Elias) What about you, bar mitzvah body?  First time you saw somebody die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes fixed on the  body) No. (catching breath) At camp... when I was fourteen... a  friend of mine was water skiing...  The motorboat ran him over... A junior  counsellor was driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should kill a man some day, David,  it's liberating... (walking out) Summer camp. I'm in business with  somebody who went to summer camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone else is silent, grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through sliders we see a small pool. Elias and Hull sit o uneaten omelets. Both still shaken by the previous scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, man... He was always nice to  my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd a guy like you get into this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way most drug lawyers do: clients  paid me in product, and I had to  move it. Soon I was doing more dealing  than law. But this was '83, '84,  there was so much money we thought  it would never end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And now...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road gets rougher. Cocaine's a  dying business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are always going to want to  get high. Every society has ways to  alter consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they can't bear reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) We all need our delusions, only the  means change: psychedelics, opiates,  prayer, orgies, human sacrifice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias puts a finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Why aren't you selling it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: With a million dollars, I could  produce enough for a limited market  at about two bucks a pop. (makes a face: fair) But then with five million, or better  yet ten, the cost would drop to thirty  cents, and we'd have enough for the  whole world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to put two hundred fifty  thousand into your corporate account.  You cheat me, Randy, I'll use your  bladder for a bagpipe. (to Hull, with a  vengeance) We're going to put Barbosa out of  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias is very happy. He leads Hull out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the pyramid chart there's a black border around Ivy's  photo, as around Eddie's. A photo of Hull is now on the b beside the one of Elias. Hull stares out the window, lost thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Synthetic shit?? Sounds like a 20/20  segment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull shrugs: it's not that important. Carver turns to his real interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) So, what was it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking out) What was what like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Popping Ivy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm God, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks back out) Then you should know how it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver smiles, but he's non-plussed by Hull's new detachm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't clear it with me. You're  getting independent. That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) How're we coming on Gallegos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He supplies Barbosa. To get to him  we'll have to take quantity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you've got to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what killing Ivy did. I'll  get to him soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver's impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing him to the  door) I want you to get a new apartment.  Something expensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That shithole? You're big time now.  Act it. And get some clothes. Spend  money. Have fun. That's an order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull in a new, expensive suit, gives the big Blonde Woman cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether I'm here or not, no one else  uses that room. And change the linen  twice a week, just like now. (starts to go, stops,  more money) And make sure James gets what he  needs. And something for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He adds another bill. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Views, open space, expensive furnishings. Hull (in anothe fancy suit) is hanging a couple of Betty's masks. He's  meticulous about their placement. Elias wanders out from the other rooms, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed, envious) Nice place. Nice suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull has a moment of self-consciousness about the suit, c himself out in a mirror -- a private moment. Elias flops on a couch, puts his feet on an antique coffe table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries over, lifts Elias feet to the floor. Hull brus the wood, inspects it carefully, fusses, worries... Elias amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pick all this shit out yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Jewish lady in the store helped  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock touched by racial  harmony) Aw... Very nice. Understated. I'm  impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull starts to place stacks of cash in a briefcase. He's  momentarily mesmerized by all the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fifty bucks, fifty fucking bucks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sold it all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'll order a couple more keys from  Barbosa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (afraid of that) I don't want to push it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. We've got a bigger territory,  we need more product. I want to deal  directly with Gallegos. It would  save us money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa'll never let us near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull closes the briefcase, ushers Elias toward the door.  He's going out, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we buy twenty, Gallegos'll come  to us himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I bought a key from Eddie, you  came to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias laughs, surprised, afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who's above Gallegos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guzman, but he's... Don't ask so  many questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How else will I learn? (hint of a threat) Call Barbosa, David, put in our  order... Because we have to split  this, and there isn't enough here  for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias feels the threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite the CLOSED sign, a light's on inside. Hull knocks No response. He keeps knocking without let-up until:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Nobody's home, go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knocks harder. Finally she appears in the doorway, sto short when she sees it's him. She's immediately aware of  white streaks on her grey suit. she tries to brush them o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't want to let  him in) Look, I'm tired, why don't you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull holds up the briefcase. She sighs, unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bill counter toting up the cash. She watches it fixedly avoid looking at him, but she feels the chemistry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you look at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I look at you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you know something I don't.  Like you're better than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That catches Hull off-guard, and he responds with a cando she didn't expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm better than you. I  don't think I'm better than anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's startled by this remark and instinctively drawn to  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) But I do know something... You can't  stop thinking about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassed, she looks away. He takes her hand, and at hi touch something yields to her. She lets him draw her to h His kiss is strangely tender, searching. It turns Betty o incredibly. She melts into him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go back here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him into...

dialogues.speaker: THE SMALL OFFICE
dialogues.text: She's sweet and loving, but her sweetness scares her. He' all over her, but she pulls back for a moment. There is a couch and before it a coffee table with coke scattered on plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates coke) Do this... do it with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She offers him a straw. He doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is where I'm at. You want to be  with me, it's gotta be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never have, never will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for fuck-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, you're not a  nigger? You're a nigger as much as  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's angry, hurt, confused, wants to love him, but feels won't let her, or she won't let herself. It's torment. Fi she's released by a KNOCK on the door. She goes out to...

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT OF THE STORE
dialogues.text: Lets in Elias. He smells the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused, jealous) Having fun? (neither answers; to  Hull) I talked to Barbosa. He'll see us  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull turns to Betty. Both want to go that way instead of  this, but events are leading somewhere else. He follows E out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC pouring into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids dancing to a live STAGE ACT. High in a wall: a lit  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very different from the club. A comfortable room with a b tables, filled with men much older than the dancers below Barbosa and Gopher at the bar with Elias and Hull. Chino other SHADOWY FIGURES lurk in the room's depths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten kilos? You're always late on  two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not ten... twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa's impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) The more we have, the more we can  move. There're markets we can't open  because we don't have the inventory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa's coked to the eyeballs, mean and dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally some balls on this team... (taunting Elias) Come work for me, John. I'll give  you your own franchise. You can supply  Elias, lean on him when he's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm with David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? He give you his "designer drugs"  pitch. He's never going to do it.  He's a shmuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to you at all. I'm  talking to John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the cocaine. Don't listen to  him. Felix, you've had enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shmuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias goes for him. He's fast and strong, and it takes Ch and Hull to pull him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise God they don't let guns in  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "None of that in here..." "Take it  outside..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa's laughing, but his cheek is flecked with his own blood, and his eyes are dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, you've been working out, you're  getting strong. Are you quick, too? (shadow boxes) Come on, I'll give you a shot at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time, any place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, right now. Do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his hands out, palms up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This? What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you slap me, I slap you. (mimes that game) Come on, it's fun. Like summer camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't look fun. Elias glances at Hull for guidance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't waste your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of this. (to Elias) Come on, you can do it, David, you're  not a shmuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias puts his hands out, palms up. Barbosa covers them w his own. ON THE HANDS: Barbosa's broad, muscular with thi gold rings and a Rolex; Elias's paler, slighter, a weddin band and a slim watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Slap my hands. Just slap them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias looks Barbosa in the eye. He's trying to be a snake but he's more the mouse. He looks away and as he does tri to... Slap him with both hands but hits only... Air. The room breathes. Barbosa turns his rings so the bi surfaces point down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now it's my turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Barbosa's turn. He's gonna kill  the white boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you went, Davey, now it's my  turn. First to four wins, like the  World Series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias covers Barbosa's palms with his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I can't look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE HANDS: Barbosa tenses his hands. Elias yanks back. Barbosa's hands haven't moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember the rules? If you flinch,  I get to hit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps Elias across the face. Hull starts forward. A kn appears. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Again, shmuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias covers Barbosa's hands. Barbosa tenses. Elias holds firm, and Barbosa quickly slaps both hands, hard. Elias  doubles over, holding his hands in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps him again, a stinging crack. Elias looks to Hull but they're across a canyon. Hull lowers his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and it hurts. Mercy, it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE HANDS. Barbosa moves his hands a millimeter, and E flinches again. Barbosa smacks him across the face. The s reverberates through the room. Now even Gopher is silent. Tears run from Elias's eyes, blood from his mouth, but he doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix! No mas. Finito.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: steps forward out of the shadows. He is young, mid-30's,  handsome, European features, beautifully dressed, accompa by a guard we'll know as MOLTO. Someone murmurs to someon else:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallegos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull reacts. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fight is over! The Ambassador  from the South has spoken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refusing any mercy) One more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa shakes his head, ashamed now in front of Gallegos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) One more! We're not finished! (people are silent) Four was the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hands. Barbosa resumes the stance, then  waits, waits, waits, and finally brings both hands down,  terribly hard, the sound of the slap is awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's it. Get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull leads Elias to the door right past Gallegos. Their g meet again. As they go out they hear Gallegos BERATING Ba in furious Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trembling, Elias holds his bloody hands against his chest as Hull leads him in silence down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. Look at me, damn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He barely whispers, but it's like a shout. Hull, who'd be avoiding his gaze, forces himself to look. Elias's humili is so profound it almost ennobles him. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed it. They taught me what I  needed to know. That I'm not part of  them, and I never will be. That they  don't respect me. That I don't deserve  respect. Because I'm a shmuck, John.  I'm a shmuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs a terrible laugh. The door behind them opens, a Barbosa appears with Gopher. Everyone is ready for death, but:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, I'm sorry. It's a crazy time,  and... you know... I'm doing a little  too much coca... I'll buy your kid a  pony... anything you want... Let's  forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes down the stairs, offers his hand. Elias will nev forget about it, but he silently takes the hand, holds th in his own bloody paws, looking directly into Barbosa's f Barbosa becomes uneasy, manages to extract his hand. Elia and Hull continue down and out the door. Gopher gushes to Barbosa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so proud of you. You can be  cruel, and you can be kind. And just  now you were kind. Proud, proud, and  more proud. That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa, Gopher with Hernandez, Taft's partner. Now we kn Hernandez is corrupt: that's how they knew Eddie was talk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got nothing to give you, my man.  I'm an il-liquid son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix, I keep telling them, "I have  informants down there, I'm working  guys, I can't say who..." If you  don't have money, give me busts, or  they're gonna start wondering about  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're already wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) You can have Gopher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Gawd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knows who he means) Felix, don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he knows, too) Great, lawyers are great, Jewish is  best. But I need spades, too. The  politicians want dark facts to scare  the suburbs so they'll vote  Republican.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lawyers and spades; I got the  trifecta: two dealers and a girl who  does their wash. Two niggers and a  kike; all Democrats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my man. And afterwards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hernandez rubs thumb against fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When this is over, I'll send you to  Hawaii, Maui. It's very beautiful in  Maui, it's a very spiritual place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't trust that man when he's  out of rifle range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa looks tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing;  premonition of  disaster) Don't do this, Felix. It'll go wrong.  Kill Elias if you have to, honey,  but don't set him up for this. It  damages your prestige.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa faces his cocaine. He tries to resist the pull, t yields. He does another line. It's his friend. He loves i He picks up a cellular phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, you're awake, I'm impressed...  I'm sorry about what happened...  Listen, I'll get you twenty boxes,  like you wanted. You were right, you  should have what you need... Tomorrow  night... Bring your partner and that  girl with the store, Betty... I need  her advice on something. I want us  to have fun, like we used to. We'll  go to that shrimp place, okay?...  Good... Me, too, David. (hangs up; does another  line; drawing it  deep into him) Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull jacked up, excited, pleased with himself. As he pace Carver observes his beautiful suit, shoes, expensive watc He looks much better than Carver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're getting twenty kilograms  tomorrow. (notes the lightening  sky) Tonight. I made it happen. I pushed  Elias, now he doesn't make a move  without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You run Elias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I control him. Barbosa's selling it  to us because he thinks I can move  it... (now the big news) And last night I met Ramon Gallegos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver sits up fast. Hull likes that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) We're getting the dope from him;  it's still coming through Barbosa,  but Gallegos will approach me soon  on his own. We're going to get him,  Gerry. We're going to bring him and  the whole thing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver sits back, grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out window) My problem? My problem is that you  don't really know what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic) Oh, so, tell me what's happening,  Gerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbosa is setting you up tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dealing you to Taft and  Hernandez. You're going to be taken  down as you receive the drugs. They're  putting together the arrest team  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That rocks Hull. He is up, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay away. We're going to take  them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Elias and Betty? Don't be silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boss wants a bust right now. He  goes before the oversight committee  next week. He needs something to  justify the budget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imploring) I'll get him something. Give me ten  days, and I'll get him Gallegos on a  plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. The whole thing's set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerry, what are you telling me? I  need Elias... and Betty. You arrest  them, and you're throwing away  everything I've set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's out of my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) John, don't go near that bust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias (no sleep) driving. Betty in front. Hull in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shouldn't go to them. Maybe them  come to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull into the lot of a boarded up restaurant where  Barbosa and Chino stand outside of a limousine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taft and Hernandez in the same van that was outside the g earlier. They're watching THROUGH BINOCULARS, night scope They spot Elias's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering into radio) Here they are. Nobody move until we  see the green suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two groups meeting. Barbosa gives Betty a courtly kis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flirtatious) I'm sorry for dragging you out so  late, but I have to be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gives me confidence.

dialogues.speaker: HULL
dialogues.text: watching planes descend into the airport, nervous. He kno what's coming, but how does he handle it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see what we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elias takes a satchel out of the rent-a-car trunk. Chino  opens the limousine's trunk. Inside is an over-sized day- green plastic suitcase. He is about to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; spotting  the police van in  the adjacent lot) Don't touch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at him, then the direction he's looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's wrong. What's that van  doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks. They can barely see the van. Hull pulls a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is a bust. The minute we take  the stuff, they'll be over us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
